If airlines in other countries can successfully accommodate peanut allergies by removing nuts from their economy class, why can't domestic airlines in the US achieve the same level of allergy-friendly service?
If foreign carriers can accommodate passengers with nut allergies more effectively, why should domestic airlines not follow their lead to ensure the safety of allergy-prone passengers?

atraveller_82_2.input:
atraveller: "Our only trouble came with Delta.
On flights to and from Atlanta to El Salvador, I requested a nutfree buffer zone as listed as an option on the Delta website.
This request was not observed on either flight,
and I when mentioned it to the cabin crew on one segment, they began taking back the nuts from the passengers around us, pointing out that they couldn't have it because "that little boy is allergic."
This made us very uncomfortable, but at least the other passengers were polite about it.
I find it amazing that people get so incensed about "their rights" to have nuts being infringed upon.
I have a feeling that these are the same people who would be the first to complain when a plane has to make an emergency landing when a nutallergic passenger goes into anaphylaxis."

cqs.cq: Will prioritizing the rights of nut-allergic passengers lead to a higher risk of in-flight medical emergencies, potentially outweighing the benefits of accommodating their needs?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that people who request a nut-free buffer zone on a flight are the same individuals who would complain about an emergency landing for a nut-allergic passenger?

If a person with a peanut allergy has their life put at risk by a fellow passenger's snack, does that not make their rights to a nut-free environment comparable to a person of color's rights to a prejudice-free society?
If your concern for the rights of nut-allergic passengers is genuine, why do you not acknowledge the rights of nut-free buffer zone requesters to a safe travel experience?

cd38_220_1.input:
cd38: "As someone who carries an epipen for beestings,
I understand that allergies can be serious and life threatening.
Banning airlines from serving peanuts inflight seems reasonable;
several posts mention the risk inherent in many people opening bags of peanuts at one time
(which can easily happen when snacks are served)
throwing a large amount of dust in the air,
which could be enough to trigger an allergy in severely allergic people.
However, banning people from carrying on their own snacks does seem to violate their rights,
to eliminate what seems like an extremely small risk to allergysufferers.
Nuts are a healthy, portable form of protein,
and cannot be replaced by pretzels.
No, being hungry or not eating protein won't kill someone;
but, I'm a vegetarian,
and  I fly constantly, often on longhaul international flights, but mainly between the east and west coasts,"

cqs.cq: If banning peanuts from in-flight service results in a significant reduction in severe allergic reactions, then why do passengers with severe allergies not have the right to take their own allergy medication on board?
Do you have any data to support the claim that the risk of peanuts being opened in-flight is significant enough to warrant banning passengers from carrying their own snacks?

If the airline industry is willing to accommodate the needs of allergy sufferers by banning peanuts, why not also provide a safe alternative snack option to individuals who carry their own food on flights?
If banning peanuts on flights is reasonable to protect allergy sufferers, shouldn't banning personal snacks be equally reasonable to prevent accidental exposure?

cd38_220_2.input:
cd38: "The return flight is 6 ½ hours (plus commute time to the airport);
when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,
but if my mother is having a bad day, that's not always possible.
On a recent trip, I didn't have time to eat anything at all the day I flew home; got stuck in traffic and barely made my flight (I was the last one on) so didn't have time to eat or buy anything at the airport; and as we started to taxi, the flight crew announced that we had a nut allergy on board, and that they (JB) would not be serving cashews and requested that we not eat any nuts we may have brought on board.
6 ½ hours feels pretty long at that point!
No, it didn't kill me,
but it does seem that if JB hadn't served cashews, the risks involved in one or two people eating nuts they may have brought with them would have been extremely, extremely small....
and, NOTHING in life is riskfree.
I understand that people want to minimize the risks for their loved ones,
but you cannot eliminate the risk completely, regardless of what legislation you put in place.
If I ate peanuts at the airport, didn't wash my hands, and then opened the rest room door on the plane immediately before a peanut allergy sufferer, that person could suffer a reaction.
I can support airlines not serving peanuts/peanut products,
thereby eliminating the most likely possible cause of a peanutrelated incident on a flight;
but not restrictions on what people may choose to eat."

cqs.cq: Does the potential risk of a passenger bringing nuts on a flight outweigh the inconvenience of not being able to eat them?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that completely eliminating all potential allergens from flights is possible and would significantly reduce peanut-related incidents?
If airlines can ban passengers from bringing on board items that pose a risk to others, why can't they ban passengers from wearing items that pose a risk to others, such as perfume or cologne?
If complete elimination of risks is not possible, why should we restrict the freedom of choice in what foods are allowed on flights when the risk of an incident is extremely small?

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: If passengers are treated as economic units devoid of humanity, as the airline's behavior implies, why should they be entitled to compensation that acknowledges their humanity and suffering?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat?
If airlines can be held accountable for the economic burden of a flight cancellation due to bad weather, why should they not be held accountable for a bumping due to overselling?

If the airline's objective is truly to eliminate all bumping, why should the financial penalty for such an occurrence be capped at 100% of the total ticket price when it's a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity?

citizen-s_176.input:
citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,
But to assure adequate compensation and prevent airlines gaming such a requirement,
compensation should be at the average (cash) ticket price for that service class on that flight.
DOT's proposed rule using the lowest fare ticket would encourage airlines to bump those with zeroprice tickets first,
since that cost would be lowest.
As long as they continue to offer tickets for miles, airlines should not be encouraged to treat passengers using those tickets as secondclass when it comes to bumping.
The growing scarcity of actual seats for miles
something that cries out for regulatory intervention
is bad enough."

cqs.cq: If airlines were incentivized to bump passengers with zeroprice tickets first due to the lower cost, wouldn't this lead to a significant increase in bumped passengers with no compensation?
Does the proposed rule by DOT effectively incentivize airlines to unfairly discriminate against passengers with zero-price tickets, thereby undermining the intention to provide adequate compensation?
If airlines are allowed to bump passengers with zero-price tickets first due to their lower cost, wouldn't this create a de facto second-class status for those passengers?

If airlines are allowed to bump passengers with zero-price tickets first, are we not essentially treating those passengers as second-class citizens when they are using their miles, which they earned through loyalty?

darawayne_121.input:
darawayne: "The price of fuel doesn't change while I am trying to book a flight.
Maybe airlines should only be allowed to change prices once a week, or once a day, always at midnight, or something like that.
It is extremely frustrating to try to buy a ticket and have availability and/or price change while you are pushing the "Buy" button."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to dynamically change prices while customers are in the process of booking a flight, does this practice unfairly disadvantage consumers and contribute to their frustration when purchasing airline tickets?
Does any airline's current pricing policy align with the principles of consumer protection, and if not, what are the potential consequences of imposing a fixed pricing schedule?

If airline ticket prices can change dynamically to affect consumer frustration, why can't other services like hotel bookings or rental car reservations also have their prices change during the booking process?

If airlines can't control their prices in real-time to match demand, should consumers be forced to accept arbitrary price hikes when booking flights, rather than having more predictable and fair pricing practices?

darawayne_182.input:
darawayne: "This is the same as bumping and should be compensated (punishment to the airlines) as such.
It is not just the five hours, though that is bad enough; it is all the other inconveniences, arriving late at night, having to cancel engagements, having to call a cab for a long ride vs bus transportation, and a myriad other inconveniences for which the airlines in their hubris currently accepts no responsibility."
 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If the airlines frequently change flight schedules after passengers have confirmed their reservations, do you think this causes undue stress and inconvenience that should be compensated by the airlines?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that passengers are entitled to full compensation and satisfactory alternate travel arrangements whenever airlines change flight schedules after booking, considering the airlines' current change policies?

If airlines are willing to charge passengers hundreds of dollars to change their reservations for personal reasons, why shouldn't they be required to compensate passengers for the equivalent costs of their own schedule changes?

If the airlines can impose significant fees on passengers for making changes to their reservations, why shouldn't they also compensate passengers for the inconvenience caused by their own schedule changes?

JDwyer_17.input:
JDwyer: "Size of aircraft should be irrelevant.
I was trapped on a very small (approx 21 passengers) aircraft, in the hot summer sun, for hours, with no ventilation.
Outrageous!
Being cooked in a small tin can is no better than being cooked in a big one!"

cqs.cq: If aircraft size is deemed irrelevant to passenger comfort, why should passengers be subjected to potentially hazardous conditions such as overheating in a small aircraft?
Can you provide evidence from the aviation industry or scientific research that supports your claim that the size of an aircraft has no impact on passenger comfort or safety?
If being trapped in a small aircraft is no worse than being trapped in a larger one, would a small jail cell be considered no worse than a larger one?
If being cooked in a small aircraft is no worse than being cooked in a large one, why should aircraft size be a factor in safety regulations?

JJMurray_140.input:
JJMurray: "Make the compensation exactly what it is intended to be...
the cost (or double the cost) of the ticket, no cap since there is no cap on how much you may pay for that ticket.
Frequent flyer miles should simply be refunded
or a double amount refunded
in the same way as a cash ticket is handled.
Keep this simple and it will work much better.
On smaller flights, use the same rules.
Again, keep it simple.
Best way to give passengers information is to post it online, on a legible sign in the gate area, and in print large enough to read on tickets.
If people won't take the time to read at least one of those sources then they only have themselves to blame for not knowing about this."

cqs.cq: If the airline industry does not implement such a policy, do you think passengers will become frustrated with the lack of transparency and clarity in their frequent flyer redemption process?
Does any airline currently use this compensation policy for frequent flyer miles in a manner consistent with JJMurray's proposal?

If airline companies can make their policies more transparent and fair by clearly posting information about compensation, why can't the government implement similar measures to provide reparations for historical injustices?
If the compensation for frequent flyer miles is meant to be the cost of the ticket, why should it be doubled in the event of a cancelled flight?

JJMurray_143.input:
JJMurray: "No, no, no!
If you have an allergy to peanuts and you know you have it then take your own precautions.
If I decide to bring a bag of peanuts onboard an airplane and am then told I'm in a "peanut free zone" or something like that, then my rights have been trampled as have the rights of everyone in that zone.
Request peanut free services from the airlines for yourself,
but do not force those restrictions on the rest of the flying public.
I have no problem with the airline offering peanut free foods, etc.
but it should be an option that people can select
not a requirement for everyone else to abide by.
What's next?
Can I have all perfume banned from an airplane or have people wearing them banned?
How about deodorants, hair sprays, any product with latex in it?
It is not a "right" if you have to impose that behavior on others for yourself."

cqs.cq: If people with severe peanut allergies are forced to fly in a peanut-free environment, will it lead to a slippery slope where other individuals with allergies or sensitivities demand similar accommodations, potentially infringing on the rights of others?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the restrictions you propose would have a significant impact on the safety and well-being of individuals with peanut allergies?

If a person has a severe allergy that requires them to take precautions, would it not be comparable to having a disability, and therefore should they be accommodated with a separate space, just as those with disabilities are?
If you claim that you have a right to not be exposed to peanuts on a plane, then are you also advocating for a complete ban on all in-flight amenities that could potentially cause an allergy?

JJMurray_166.input:
JJMurray: "I have no problem with airlines developing their own policies vice a mandated government requirement
but whatever those policies are they need to be easy to find, easy to read and understandable by your "average" person before someone books and pays for a flight.
If you want to regulate this then insist that all policies related to overbooking, rebooking, rerouting, basically any changes to the originally contracted flight must be made available in a format that is easily accessible and understandable to the general public."

cqs.cq: If airlines' policies are not made easily accessible and understandable to the general public, can consumers accurately make informed decisions about their flights, or are they at risk of being misled and potentially suffering from negative consequences?

Can you provide a scientific study that demonstrates a correlation between easily accessible and understandable airline policies and increased consumer satisfaction, considering other factors such as price and flight reliability?

If airlines are allowed to develop their own policies on overbooking and rebooking, why wouldn't they be required to provide clear and easily accessible information about these policies to passengers, just like they would be if government regulations mandated such transparency?

If airlines are allowed to develop their own policies, wouldn't that lead to a lack of consistency and fairness across the industry, potentially harming consumers who cannot easily compare and navigate different airlines' policies?

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: If banning peanuts from planes is not sufficient to prevent peanut exposure, then why not implement more stringent cleaning protocols to minimize the risk of peanut residue on aircraft surfaces?
Do you have a scientific study or data that supports the claim that removing peanuts from airplanes would be sufficient to minimize the risk of anaphylaxis for passengers with peanut allergies?

If removing peanuts from planes is deemed a reasonable measure to prevent severe allergic reactions, why not ban all foods that pose a choking hazard, such as popcorn or grapes, to further minimize the risk of in-flight incidents?

If complete removal of peanuts from airplanes is deemed necessary to ensure passenger safety, then shouldn't the removal of all potential allergens and contaminants, such as gluten and dairy products, also be required?

JL_15.input:
JL: "The consumer credit industry is very highly regulated
The regulations have been over-hauled three times in the last decade"

cqs.cq: Does the high level of regulation in the consumer credit industry actually cause more harm than good to consumers?
Can you provide a specific example of a regulation in the consumer credit industry that has been overhauled in the last decade, along with a citation from a reputable source?
If consumer credit is highly regulated, why is the student loan industry, which is a form of consumer credit, not held to the same standards?
If the consumer credit industry is highly regulated, then why have the regulations needed to be over-hauled three times in the last decade?

JL_3.input:
JL: "Oh, I don’t think that’s true at all
You don’t pay an interest rate
The interest rate varies by the amount of the charge for the credit but also the time over which you repay it
So if you borrow some money from me, and you pay it back very quickly, the interest rate will be much higher than if you pay it back over a long period
But the amount it costs you is exactly the same"

cqs.cq: Does the varying interest rate based on repayment time actually affect the total cost for the borrower?

Can you provide a credible source that supports your claim that the interest rate varies by the amount of the charge for the credit but also the time over which you repay it, rather than just the amount borrowed?
If paying back a loan quickly incurs a higher interest rate, why would a person be penalized for paying off a debt more rapidly?
If you claim that the interest rate varies based on the repayment period, doesn't that imply that the bank is profiting more from longer-term loans than from shorter-term loans?

JL_5.input:
JL: "Because they’re very short-term loans
if you borrowed £200 from me, and in 30 days time you pay back £250, the interest rate on that is 1,413.01%
It sounds horrendous
...
But if you pay me back the same amount of money in six months time the interest rate is only 57.3%.
And if you take a year to pay it back it goes down"

cqs.cq: If lenders can legally charge such astronomically high interest rates for short-term loans, does this contribute to a cycle of debt that disproportionately affects low-income individuals?
Can you provide a scientific study or credible source that supports the claim that interest rates decrease proportionally with the duration of repayment periods?
If a lender can charge a 57.3% interest rate for a six-month loan, why would a six-month payday loan with a 1,413.01% interest rate not be considered predatory?

If the interest rates for these payday loans are so drastically different based on repayment time, why does this not create a financial incentive for lenders to offer more favorable terms to borrowers who are willing to repay their debts over a longer period?

JW_41.input:
JW: "It’s only since the state intervened that people have been uninterested in which bank they put their money in
In the old days of early capitalism, bankers were famously prudent people. And they went to great lengths to advertise how prudent they were.
This stopped not because of the big bang, which liberalised banking, which is what everybody thinks.
It stopped because of government guarantees to depositors."

cqs.cq: Would the state's removal of guarantees to depositors cause a renewed emphasis on prudence among bankers?
Can you provide evidence that government guarantees to depositors significantly increased consumer apathy towards banking institutions in the early capitalist era?
If prudent bankers were previously incentivized by government guarantees, would the absence of such guarantees now lead to a return to their prudence?
If prudent bankers were truly as reliable as they claimed, would their need for government guarantees to depositors have been necessary?

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.
They can't have it both ways."

cqs.cq: What would happen to airline customer satisfaction and trust if the airlines were forced to provide timely delay notifications despite the potential for unforeseen circumstances that could lead to faster-than-expected resolution of issues?

Do you have any evidence from a reputable aviation or customer service study that supports the claim that flyers are generally more responsible and less likely to file complaints when they experience unexpected flight delays?
If airlines can't accurately predict delay resolutions, why should they be expected to notify passengers of potential delays with a 30-minute warning?
If airlines are held accountable for the consequences of unpredictable events, shouldn't flyers be held accountable for not planning their trips accordingly?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: Does the current pay structure for flight crew members incentivize them to prioritize efficiency over safety, potentially causing longer flight times and increased risk of accidents?
Do you have any scientific studies that demonstrate a direct correlation between crew members' perceptions of fairness and the actual pay structure in the airline industry?
If pilots and flight attendants are not paid for the full time they spend on the ground, would this not be analogous to paying workers for a 40-hour workweek but only compensating them for 20 hours?

If the flight crew's pay structure is poorly designed, then why do airlines not revise their compensation policies to align with the actual flight times, rather than sticking to the outdated block-to-block system?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

cqs.cq: Will exceeding the 3 hour limit on ground delays cause more damage to air travel than the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry that supports the claim that flights canceling due to the 3-hour limit are not a significant problem, compared to the problems caused by subsequent flight cancellations?
Is it fair to assume that a 3-hour delay would be comparable to a 3-hour wait in traffic, considering the vastly different circumstances and potential consequences of each?
Does the 3-hour limit effectively balance airline efficiency with passenger comfort and compensation, or does it unfairly penalize travelers with no recourse?

KHenrickson_172.input:
KHenrickson: "The notification isn't so much a problem at most airports.
The electronic boards are usually updated minute by minute.
The problem is that the airlines will say "Flight 100, delayed till 7:00pm." then "Flight 100, delayed till 7:05pm".  And so on and so forth.
They're notifying everyone...with completely useless information.
Forcing them to do so more frequently isn't going to fix a thing.
Forcing them to come up with an accurate estimate is what is needed."

cqs.cq: If the frequent, minute-by-minute updates are causing frustration rather than providing useful information, does this not ultimately lead to a decrease in customer satisfaction with airport notification systems?

Can you provide evidence from the aviation industry that suggests frequent minute-by-minute updates on flight delays are more effective than providing accurate initial estimates in reducing passenger frustration?

If airlines are required to update flight information frequently with minor adjustments, would this resemble the practice of constantly revising and refining a plan rather than having a clear, accurate strategy?

If the airlines are already updating the electronic boards frequently with minute-by-minute information, why would increasing the frequency of updates, rather than improving the accuracy of the information, truly address the problem?

MP_22.input:
MP: "Well, you say the banks are the lenders
there are lots of other people who are lenders too
I mean everyone who puts money into a bank, or a building society, is putting it there so that the bank can lend it on
I mean you just heard Simon Rose say
there’s been 100 billion pounds transfer from savers to borrowers
So if you're going to raise your banner for anybody who’s doing badly in this situation, I would have thought you might have raised it for savers, in the first instance"

cqs.cq: If savers are the ones who are ultimately providing the funds for lending, why should they not have greater influence over the lending decisions made by banks?
Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that savers are being exploited by banks, rather than simply being a necessary component of the lending process?
If the banks are seen as lenders, why wouldn't savers, who are also lending their money, be considered lenders as well?
If savers are also lenders, and banks are transferring 100 billion pounds from them to borrowers, does that not make savers also responsible for the economic consequences of lending?

MP_48.input:
MP: "	I think it’s very interesting that capitalism is coming under such a lot of attack here
And I don’t say that’s inappropriate
But we haven’t yet attacked democracy
I mean one of the things that strikes me about this is that when you have incumbent governments, and they see that consumer credit boom mushrooming and mushrooming, what do they do?
They don’t want to stop it
They don’t want to stop it, because they want voters.
They want voters who feel artificially rich
because voters who feel artificially rich will probably vote for the incumbent"

cqs.cq: If voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for the incumbent, then does this create a self-perpetuating cycle where politicians prioritize policies that fuel consumer debt rather than addressing underlying economic issues?
Can you provide evidence from scientific studies to support the claim that governments deliberately foster consumer credit booms to increase voter loyalty?
If governments prioritize voters who feel artificially rich over genuine economic growth, does this resemble a form of corruption that undermines the principles of democracy?
If politicians benefit from voters who feel artificially wealthy, doesn't that imply that democracy can be corrupted by the influence of consumer credit?

MR_TELEVOID__178.input:
MR: "Maybe you're just the only one who gives a shit about their hair"
 < this message is answering to > 
XxEnder: "Am I the only one who noticed that Bernie combed his hair"

cqs.cq: If Bernie's hair is indeed combed, then why is that a notable aspect of his appearance?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that one's concern for personal grooming is a reliable indicator of their empathy towards others?
If Bernie's hair is considered noteworthy for its natural appearance, why is that same natural appearance seen as unprofessional in people of color?
If Bernie's hair is truly a non-issue, then why are you bringing it up?

MT_10.input:
MT: "we know from lots and lots of research, you know this, that people aren’t very good at understanding financial products
And they're easily seduced into acting, in the short-term, in ways which aren’t very good for them in the long-term
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?"

cqs.cq: Does the financial services industry's history of preying on consumers' financial ignorance justify stricter regulations to protect them from its predatory practices?

Can you provide evidence from academic research that supports the claim that the financial services industry has a deep commitment to exploiting consumers' weaknesses, rather than merely responding to market demand?
If financial institutions can exploit people's weaknesses to generate profits, why wouldn't they engage in similar manipulations with people's emotions and biases?
Doesn't the financial services industry's history justify skepticism about its ability to genuinely prioritize consumers' well-being over profits?

MT_40.input:
MT: "I don’t think you just said the opposite of them was neutral
So if they're virtues, doesn’t that imply that the opposite of thrift and prudence is immoral?
But, hold on
Isn’t it simply the case that buying a cup of coffee is something which is substantially less demanding than working up a long-term interest rate?
Therefore isn’t it a reasonable thing for the state to intervene in those cases
because the knowledge is bounded?"

cqs.cq: Does the state's intervention in less demanding choices, such as buying a cup of coffee, not set a precedent that could lead to overreach in more complex, demanding decisions, such as working up a long-term interest rate?
Do you have a philosophical or economic source that supports the notion that the state should intervene in market transactions based on perceived bounded knowledge?
If a government intervening in economic transactions is seen as reasonable when the knowledge is bounded, why wouldn't that be the case for financial institutions?

Isn't it the case that the state's intervention in buying a cup of coffee is a slippery slope that could justify its involvement in other, more demanding aspects of life, undermining the very concept of virtues like thrift and prudence?

Melanie_64.input:
Melanie: "Well the State has taken a moral position
that position was non-judgmentalism
and terrible harm it’s done
It’s created a lot of victims who now need help themselves, and who sometimes go on to create other victims through crime
 I think they do need help
but that help should be very carefully calibrated, to restore the capacity for independence and personal responsibility"

cqs.cq: Does non-judgmentalism in the State's position lead to a lack of accountability among its victims, causing further harm to themselves and others?
Can you provide evidence from scientific research that supports the claim that non-judgmentalism has led to a significant increase in victims who go on to create other victims through crime?

If non-judgmentalism has led to a loss of independence and personal responsibility among some individuals, would a more calibrated approach to help similarly enable those who have been victimized by crime to regain these qualities?
If the State has taken a moral position of non-judgmentalism that has led to more victims, can it truly claim to be helping those in need without enabling further harm?

Mpogoda_184.input:
Mpogoda: "As a frequent traveler, I would welcome the rule requiring 24 hour refundability of fares + all fees.
Additionally, there should be a certain window,
say, 3 days prior to flying where you should be able to cancel your flight without penalty and receive a refund or at least the ability to change your itinerary without fee.
As I always say to all who will listen,
the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;
and lastly, being treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane."

cqs.cq: Does the airline industry's poor customer service and numerous fees lead to a decrease in customer satisfaction and loyalty?
Can you provide evidence from the airline industry that contradicts your assertion that the current model is one of the worst business models you know of?
If airline companies are allowed to nickel and dime customers with extra fees, would they be any different from loan sharks?
If airline business models are so exploitative and inconsiderate, why should consumers be expected to pay extra for a 24-hour refundability of fares?

MrFordization__82.input:
MrFordization: "Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat
Maybe he just knows more than you"

cqs.cq: Does classifying global warming as a national security threat by the Pentagon justify a more significant role for the military in addressing this issue?
Can you provide a peer-reviewed scientific study that supports the claim that global warming is not a national security threat?

If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, would that not imply that the effects of climate change pose a similar level of danger to the nation as the threats that Mr. Ford is addressing?
If global warming is a national security threat, then why should Mr. Ford's stance on it be prioritized over the scientific consensus?

Mulder_112.input:
Mulder: "Your argument is a strawman.
Nobody is advocating funerals;
you're just trying to deflect attention away from the issue,
which is that there is no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers.
And there is no scientific evidence to support your argument.
You can't even cite the studies you claim exist,
because they don't exist.
The only mean spirited people are those like yourself, who want to trample the rights of the majority for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people.
This has nothing to do with the founding of the U.S. at all."

cqs.cq: If the lack of scientific evidence to support the argument of a real risk to peanut allergy sufferers causes widespread public support for the policy, then why should their rights be disregarded for the sake of a perceived risk that affects a small minority?
Can you provide a reputable scientific study that supports the claim that peanut allergies pose a significant risk to the general public?
If arguing against a risk to the majority that doesn't exist, would you also dismiss the historical injustices inflicted on a minority group that are well-documented and acknowledged?
If there's no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers, then why are you advocating for measures that restrict the rights of the majority for the sake of a group with a perceived risk?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: If a child with a severe peanut allergy can die from exposure to peanut dust or oil even with the use of an epipen, then why is it unreasonable to assume that exposure to peanut dust or oil on an airplane poses a significant risk?
Can you provide evidence from a reputable medical source that suggests an epipen would be ineffective in saving a child's life in the event of a severe peanut allergy reaction?
If a severe peanut allergy is acknowledged as a legitimate reason for a child to avoid flying, why not also acknowledge a severe fear of flying as a legitimate reason to avoid it?
If people with severe food allergies are advised to live in a bubble, as you claim, then why do you expect others to accommodate your child's needs by banning peanuts on airplanes?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: Is it logical to assume that banning peanuts on airplanes would have a significant impact on the overall public health, given the far greater risk of death from other causes?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that peanut consumption on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace comparable to tobacco smoking?
If serving peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, why is advocating for banning peanuts on planes not as extreme as banning driving, a more likely cause of death?
If serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace, then why should we treat it as one and restrict its distribution on airplanes?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people don’t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isn’t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: If the government continues to incentivize certain types of behavior through economic policies, won't this lead to further exacerbating the economic disparities between those who have access to productive investments and those who do not?

Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that South Korea's economic policies incentivized saving, when in fact the data suggests that consumer debt has been a significant driver of economic growth in the country?

If South Korea's economic policies incentivize saving and productive investments, why should we not implement similar policies to incentivize investments in the lower-income sectors of our own society?
If the government incentivizes certain types of behavior to promote economic growth, are there any comparable incentives being offered to those who need financial support the most?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to charge passengers based on their weight, would this policy lead to a decrease in the number of passengers willing to fly, ultimately affecting the airline industry's revenue?
Does any reputable scientific study support the claim that body weight is a reliable indicator of an individual's ability to safely carry luggage on an aircraft?

If airlines can legally discriminate against obese individuals based on weight, why can't they also legally discriminate against passengers based on their socioeconomic status, age, or other characteristics?
If weight-based airline fees are considered discriminatory, then why shouldn't size-based fees also be considered discriminatory?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: If seat size and configuration are considered a health issue, then why are they not treated as a matter of public health concern rather than a matter of airline convenience?
Do you have a medical professional's opinion that supports the claim that seat size and configuration constitute a health issue?

If airline companies can charge for seat size and configuration as a health issue, why can't they be held accountable for the health risks associated with pet owners being forced to check their pets, which can lead to fatal stress and anxiety?

If airlines are held accountable for promoting passenger health by providing space for in-flight exercises, why shouldn't they also be held accountable for providing sufficient space for passengers themselves?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: Will banning peanuts on flights or in areas where allergy sufferers are present cause more harm than good by inadvertently exposing those with inhalation allergies to other potential allergens?

Do you believe that the airline industry could effectively enforce a ban on peanuts and other allergenic foods on flights when a passenger requests it, without causing significant inconvenience to other passengers?

If airlines are required to accommodate a peanut allergy by removing peanuts from flights when requested, why wouldn't they be required to accommodate other severe food allergies by removing other foods when requested?
If banning peanuts on flights is necessary for the safety of those with a peanut allergy, then should we also ban all foods on flights when a passenger requests it to ensure their safety?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: If peanuts and items containing peanuts are left on airplanes and cause a severe reaction in a passenger, do you think the airline's liability would be greater than the cost of removing them?

Do you have a scientific study that demonstrates a significant correlation between peanut presence on planes and severe allergic reactions in passengers, to justify the removal of peanuts from all airlines?
If peanuts on planes pose a risk to passengers due to crumbs, whole peanuts, and residue, why not also ban other potential allergens like tree nuts, shellfish, and gluten-containing products?
If peanuts are a significant allergen risk on planes, why not remove all high-risk foods and not just peanuts?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if frequent exposure to peanuts on commercial flights causes severe allergic reactions in passengers, thereby affecting the airline's reputation and overall customer satisfaction?

Do airline industry experts agree that the proposed rule requiring removal of peanuts and implementation of repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be a more cost-effective and effective approach to ensuring passenger safety compared to requiring airlines to provide EpiPens?
If airlines are not required to provide EpiPens for passengers with severe allergies, why would they be required to take extensive measures to remove peanuts from their aircraft?
If severe allergy sufferers are already prepared with EpiPens, should airlines not be held responsible for preventing accidental exposure on their aircraft?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: If ticket issuers are allowed to list fees separately, might this lead to a misleading perception of a lower base fee, potentially affecting consumer purchasing decisions?
Can you provide a specific study or academic research that supports the claim that separating ticket components is inherently misleading and meaningless?
If a company can hide certain fees within a base ticket price, why should that not be allowed, but requiring transparency by listing them separately be seen as misleading?
If the goal is to show transparency in ticket pricing, why not display the entire cost upfront rather than breaking it down into separate, often unexercised, components?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: If airlines are unable to guarantee a completely peanut-free environment despite their best efforts, should they be required to accommodate passengers with severe peanut allergies?
Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the effectiveness of the measures taken by the airline to mitigate peanut exposure on the return flight?

If airlines accommodate severe peanut allergies with such vigilance, why not provide similar accommodations for other severe allergies, such as shellfish or tree nut allergies, which pose similar risks?
If the airline went to such great lengths to accommodate my son's peanut allergy, why did they fail to ensure his safety on the return trip despite their previous efforts?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: If banning peanuts from airline flights could potentially save a life, would it be unreasonable to prioritize the safety of passengers with severe peanut allergies over the financial interests of the airline industry?
Do you think that the potential risks associated with banning peanuts from airline flights outweigh the potential benefits of preventing severe allergic reactions in passengers?

If banning peanuts on flights is deemed necessary to save lives in the event of an allergy, why not also ban other potential allergens like shellfish or gluten to ensure equal safety for all passengers?
If banning peanuts on flights is necessary to save lives, why not extend this precaution to other potential allergy triggers that could cause equally life-threatening reactions?

Sithsaber__198.input:
Sithsaber: "Have you been to high school
It's shit"
 < this message is answering to > 
g: "high school is high school, college is college"

cqs.cq: Does attending high school have a significant effect on one's life trajectory and future opportunities?
Do you have a scientific study or academic research that supports the claim that the experience of high school is universally considered "shit" among students?
If high school is indeed "shit" as you claim, would that imply that the value placed on it is comparable to the value placed on other life experiences?
If high school is just high school, then why do you feel the need to degrade it as "shit"?

SofieM_128.input:
SofieM: "Keep in mind that you wouldn't be able to get out of the plane if it were in the air, either.
I think deplaning is a bit extreme,
because it could throw an already imbalanced flight schedule out of whack, and might delay flights even further or lead to cancellation.
I sat on a tarmac in London for five hours earlier this year, but I'd rather wait it out than hop off the plane and miss an opportunity to take off.
However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: If passengers are not provided with regular updates on flight delays, could this lead to a heightened sense of anxiety and frustration, ultimately affecting their mental health?
Do you believe that the potential benefits of allowing passengers to disembark during flight delays outweigh the potential disruptions it could cause to the airline's flight schedule?
If a plane being grounded on the tarmac is comparable to a person being delayed in their life, why would deplaning be seen as more extreme than staying on the plane and waiting it out?

If regular passenger updates can mitigate the frustration of a delayed flight, wouldn't deplaning passengers who are stuck on the ground for an extended period be a more effective solution to prevent further disruptions?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the fact that airlines have voluntarily provided flight notifications to customers demonstrate that the DOT's proposed rule may not be necessary to improve customer satisfaction?
Can you provide scientific evidence that supports the claim that airlines would have voluntarily implemented flight status notifications without government intervention?

If airlines like Southwest are benefiting from their customer-centric approach, why wouldn't the Department of Transportation's proposed rule, which prioritizes passenger satisfaction, also benefit airlines by increasing customer loyalty and retention?
If airlines have already implemented flight notifications to boost customer satisfaction and their profits, why do we need a federal mandate to require them to do so?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: Will a blanket policy forcing airlines to treat all minors in the same manner lead to more or fewer instances of children being able to fly unaccompanied by an adult?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support your claim that parents are more capable of determining their child's travel readiness than airlines?

If a one-size-fits-all policy for child travel safety is implemented, would it be analogous to a blanket policy requiring all students to graduate at the same age, disregarding individual differences in academic readiness?
If blanket policies are a bad idea because they don't account for individual differences, then can we trust airlines to make more nuanced decisions than a one-size-fits-all government policy?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: If she deleted 33,000 e-mails, does that imply she has something to hide?
Do you have any credible evidence or a scientific study that supports the claim that deleting 33,000 emails is a criminal act, rather than a common practice of archiving and deleting emails?
If Trump's email scandal were treated with the same severity as Clinton's, would he be facing impeachment proceedings?
If Trump claims that the release of emails is non-negotiable, then why does he have the authority to dictate what information is released?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: If a ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes could prevent severe allergic reactions from occurring in passengers, would it outweigh the inconvenience and costs associated with enforcing such a policy?

Can you provide evidence from scientific research that supports the claim that a ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes would significantly reduce the risk of an allergic reaction for those with airborne nut allergies?

If a plane is a confined space where airborne particles from food can trigger life-threatening reactions, would it not be comparable to a workplace where airborne particles from dust or chemicals can cause similar reactions?

If air travel is a necessary evil for many people, then shouldn't airline policies prioritize the safety and well-being of passengers with severe allergies, even if it means implementing a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: If airlines allow passengers to bring on and consume nuts despite having 'nut-free' flights, do you think this policy causes more harm to those who have severe nut allergies?
Is there any scientific evidence to support the claim that allowing passengers to bring and consume nuts on flights poses a significant risk to those with severe nut allergies?

If airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts but will not intervene if they're consumed, would that not create a similar scenario to allowing passengers to bring on and consume firearms?

If airlines can accommodate passengers with severe allergies by declaring a 'nut-free' flight, why can't they take proactive steps to enforce that declaration by preventing passengers from bringing and consuming nuts onboard?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: Would the implementation of a mandatory auction system for bumped passengers cause a decrease in overbooking by airlines?
Does Julian Simon's proposed auction system for compensating bumped passengers have a stronger empirical foundation than the current compensation limits in place?
If a mandatory cash payment option is deemed necessary for passengers lacking check cashing privileges, why wouldn't a similar accommodation be made for those without credit cards?

If compensation for bumped passengers is to truly serve as a deterrent to overbooking, why should it not be tied to the actual expenses incurred by the passenger, rather than being capped at a fixed limit?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: If the airlines continue to overbook flights to optimize their financial results, will this lead to a decrease in passenger satisfaction and trust, ultimately affecting their reputation and business?

Does the airline industry's history of auctioning seats and compensating passengers demonstrate a more effective way to manage overbooking than the current system, and should this approach be revisited and implemented?

If airlines are allowed to auction off seats on overbooked flights, would that not create a situation where the airline industry is essentially mimicking a real estate market where the most financially capable individuals are able to secure better accommodations?

If overbooking is an inevitable consequence of optimizing airline profits, should we tolerate involuntary denials of boarding or seek alternative solutions that balance consumer satisfaction with airline revenue?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: If airlines frequently change flight schedules without passengers' consent after booking, would this cause significant inconvenience and financial loss to passengers, ultimately affecting their travel plans and daily lives?

Do you have any scientific studies or data that support the claim that frequent flight schedule changes have a greater negative impact on passengers than the financial benefits of booking flights up to a year in advance?

If airlines can charge passengers to change their flight schedules for personal reasons, would it be fair for passengers to not be compensated when airlines change flight schedules for their own reasons?

If airlines can impose steep fees on passengers who want to change their itineraries for personal reasons, shouldn't passengers who experience involuntary schedule changes also be entitled to compensation and accommodations?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: If a complete ban on peanut products does not eliminate the risk of exposure, but merely reduces it, does this justify the inconvenience and potential negative impact on people's lives?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that a ban on peanut products would be an effective measure in reducing the risk of peanut exposure in a peanut-free table scenario?

If banning peanut products is considered an effective measure to reduce exposure risk, why wouldn't implementing stricter gun control measures be seen as a similarly effective way to reduce gun violence risk?
If a peanut-free table reduces the risk of exposure to peanut butter, does banning peanut products entirely truly eliminate the risk of exposure or merely shift it to those who sneak them?

elizwestley_68.input:
elizwestley: "I've registered my son on a flight as peanutallergic and had the attendant try to hand him a bag of peanuts.
Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: Does the lack of adequate training on peanut allergies among flight personnel cause them to make mistakes that put allergic passengers at risk?

Do airline staff receive comprehensive training on food allergy protocols and protocols to handle in-flight medical emergencies, such as anaphylaxis, to ensure they can provide adequate assistance to passengers with allergies?
