If airlines require flight attendants to undergo extensive training on medical procedures, why not train them on basic allergy protocols to ensure the safety of passengers with life-threatening conditions?
If flight personnel are supposed to be trained to handle emergency situations, then why weren't they aware of the severity of peanut allergies?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.
And 3 hours is too long to keep people on a grounded airplane."
 < this message is answering to > 
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: If aircraft are allowed to keep passengers on a grounded plane for extended periods, do you think it would lead to decreased customer satisfaction and loyalty among airline passengers?

Do you have any experience as a military member that justifies imposing a policy that would require passengers to remain in the immediate area after deplaning, given that the military's overseas contract flights are not comparable to commercial air travel?
If passengers can be forced to wait on a grounded aircraft for 3 hours, would it not be analogous to being confined to a detention center for an extended period without access to basic rights?
If the crew's primary motivation for expediency is profit, does that justify prioritizing their interests over passengers' welfare and comfort?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If passengers are charged extra for checked luggage based on their weight, do you think it would lead to a significant enough difference in airline revenue to offset the potential backlash from passengers who feel unfairly treated?
Do you have a scientific study or source that supports the claim that weight should be a factor in determining airline ticket prices?
If airlines can justify charging extra fees based on weight, would they also justify charging more for a passenger's ticket based on their height, age, or other physical characteristics?
If weight-based pricing is truly fair, then why would the airline charge a 98 lb person the same as a 250 lb person, rather than adjusting the price according to the weight difference?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed
Both should be held responsible
This is the same case for Snowden
he gave illegally acquired papers that he stole, to the Times in the hopes that they would responsible with it
They failed in that
a terrorist group was able to use the exposed information to alter their plans
It's cut and dry"

cqs.cq: If you steal information and give it to someone else, expecting them to handle it responsibly, but they fail to do so, can you still be held accountable for the consequences?
Can you provide a credible source to support the claim that giving illegally acquired information to a third party is equivalent to lending a firearm to someone who uses it to cause harm?
If someone gives a stolen key to a friend to unlock a door responsibly, but the friend accidentally breaks it, would they not be held accountable?

If one is held accountable for providing a stolen firearm that leads to an accidental death, why should Snowden not face consequences for leaking classified information that led to a terrorist attack?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Would implementing a ban on peanuts in airplanes cause more severe reactions from people with peanut allergies than taking proactive steps to accommodate their needs?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support your claim that the likelihood of a serious reaction from tree nuts is similar to that of peanuts?

If banning peanuts in schools is deemed necessary for the safety of children with peanut allergies, why wouldn't a similar ban be implemented in airline food, considering the severity of potential reactions?
If peanut allergies are viewed as a legitimate reason to impose airline restrictions, why should tree nut allergies not be treated with the same level of caution?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: Does the lack of accommodations for individuals with life-threatening allergies, such as those experienced by your child, justify the argument that food allergies are overblown or imagined?
Can you provide evidence from the scientific community that supports your claim that allergists are not doctors?
If a child's life-threatening allergies are no longer a concern by the age of 5, why would a 4-year-old child's severe allergies be taken lightly?

If your son's peanut allergy is indeed relatively mild, as you claim, then why do you believe airlines should take drastic measures to accommodate all peanut allergy sufferers, rather than simply recommending that they take precautions?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: If airlines continue to prioritize convenience over allergy safety, can they justify the risk of severe allergic reactions on their flights?
Can you provide evidence from your 3000-member online forum that substantiates your claim that peanut reactions can be life-threatening through contact or inhalation, rather than just ingestion?

If airline staff members are required to have medical training to handle life-threatening situations, why should passengers with life-threatening peanut allergies not be accommodated with more than just a buffer zone?

If you're so concerned about the financial interests of the airline industry, why wouldn't you support measures that would minimize the financial burden of accommodating peanut-free flights, such as buffer zones, rather than a full ban?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: Should the airlines' implementation of precautions be prioritized over the individual responsibility of those with severe allergies to take proactive steps to protect themselves?
Do you have a scientific study that supports your claim that individuals with severe allergies are entirely responsible for their own precautions?
If severe tree nut allergies are not being used as a reason to ban tree nuts, why should peanut allergies justify a blanket ban on peanuts?
If taking precautions is a responsibility, shouldn't the airlines and restaurants also take precautions to accommodate passengers with severe allergies?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does the existence of severe peanut allergies in a small percentage of the population justify the widespread restrictions on peanuts in public places, such as airplanes?
Can you provide any credible scientific evidence to support your claim that most food allergies are completely imagined?
If the dangers of peanuts are as extreme as they are claimed, why is it that they are allowed in most public spaces and not strictly prohibited?
If most food allergies are imagined, does that imply that a severe peanut allergy is a rare exception, and thus, does it justify the extreme measures taken to accommodate such a condition?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If peanut dust in the air can cause life-threatening reactions in individuals with severe peanut allergies, should airlines prioritize their safety by enforcing a peanut-free zone on flights?
Can you name any scientific study that supports the claim that the current airline regulations regarding peanut-free zones are insufficient to prevent life-threatening allergic reactions?
If airlines were once required to accommodate smokers' demands for smoking sections, why should they not also accommodate peanut allergy sufferers by banning peanuts altogether?
If airlines were able to effectively eliminate secondhand smoke from flights, why can't they ensure the removal of peanut dust from planes?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: Does the presence of peanuts on planes cause a significant risk of anaphylactic reactions, which can lead to severe consequences for individuals with peanut allergies?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that the benefits of allowing nuts on planes outweigh the risks to passengers with peanut allergies?

If peanut allergies pose a unique risk due to the fine particles and sticky residue of peanut butter, would requiring passengers to disclose their peanut allergy status before boarding be as effective as banning peanuts from planes?

If peanut allergies are a legitimate health concern that can cause life-threatening reactions, then why should airline companies not provide a peanut-free option to protect the well-being of their passengers with these allergies?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: If airlines were to prioritize passenger comfort and space, would the reduction in discomfort-related illnesses among passengers lead to an increase in job satisfaction and retention rates among flight attendants?
Do you have any evidence from the aviation industry or ergonomic studies that support the claim that airlines could save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design?
If ergonomically designed and comfortable airliners were prioritized, would they then be more comparable to luxury vehicles rather than necessary evils?
If airlines are prioritizing profits over passenger comfort, why should consumers continue to tolerate cramped seating when more spacious and ergonomic designs are feasible?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: If airlines allowed pets to travel in secured carriers under the seat in front of their owners, would it increase customer satisfaction and loyalty among pet owners, ultimately leading to more frequent bookings?

Do airlines have any data showing that allowing pets to travel in the cabin with their owners increases customer satisfaction and retention, thereby offsetting the potential revenue loss from the added passenger fare?
If airlines treat pets as less important than humans, why would they not also consider passengers with disabilities or special needs to be less important than those who fit into standard categories?
If airlines are so concerned about the safety of their human passengers, why can't they implement a safer and more convenient option for pet owners like you who pose no threat to flight security?

mfball__143.input:

cqs.cq: If O'Malley receives significantly more media coverage, will he be able to increase his chances of obtaining the nomination?

If Bernie Sanders was initially overlooked despite his eventual rise to prominence, can the same be said for Martin O'Malley's campaign, which seems to have been similarly underrepresented in media coverage?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: If frequent flight delays and cancellations contribute to increased anxiety and stress for passengers, will implementing strict new regulations on flight departure times alleviate this stress for passengers with anxiety issues?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that being informed every 30 minutes significantly alleviates passenger frustration and anxiety during flight delays?
If frequent delays and cancellations are seen as a necessary evil, why should the same not be considered for other forms of public transportation?

If the new rules are intended to alleviate frustration and prevent episodes, then why not extend this regulation to other forms of transportation, such as trains and buses, to ensure equal treatment for all travelers?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: If the Green Party presidential candidate is not given equal time on privately owned networks, does it effectively silence their voice and hinder the democratic process?
Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that privately owned networks have an obligation to provide equal airtime to minor party candidates?

If a privately owned news network is allowed to deny equal airtime to a presidential candidate based on their party affiliation, wouldn't this set a precedent where other forms of media and public forums could do the same?

If a private news network has no obligation to provide equal airtime to a Green Party candidate, why should it not be allowed to deny airtime to any candidate that doesn't pose a realistic threat to the major parties?

secretcurse__139.input:

According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: If the first debate was already limited to five people, why should the 166 other candidates who have filed with the FEC be given equal time and consideration in a democratic process?
Do you have a credible source that supports the idea that a fair shot at the first debate means equal representation for all 171 candidates?
If the first debate was limited to five people, would a fair representation of the 171 candidates be equivalent to a fair representation of the general population?
If only a select few are chosen for the first debate, are we implying that the rest of the candidates' voices and perspectives are not worthy of being heard?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: Would imposing regulations on the airline industry cause a decrease in airline profits, potentially resulting in reduced customer service?

Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that imposing common sense regulations on the airline industry would effectively level the playing field and improve customer service without stifling airline profits?

If commercial airline travel is likened to a "race to the bottom" in terms of service quality, why would imposing regulations be comparable to leveling the playing field in a traditional sporting event?
If airlines can only survive by cutting corners and sacrificing service, does that not imply that the current system is fundamentally flawed?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: If passengers are forced to deplane and experience considerable time lost due to delays, will their overall travel experience and airline satisfaction suffer as a result?
Do you have a scientific study that supports the claim that the potential health benefits of deplaning outweigh the potential inconvenience of lost time for passengers?
If a 6-hour flight from the gate is deemed long enough to warrant offering passengers food and drink, why does a 6-hour delay on the ground not justify similar accommodations?
If deplaning is indeed a significant inconvenience, then shouldn't airlines provide a basic level of sustenance to passengers who are stuck on a plane for extended periods?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: What if serving dinner at a delayed time causes passengers to experience hunger-related health issues that affect their overall comfort and satisfaction with the flight experience?

Do you have a medical or aviation expert opinion that supports the claim that delaying dinner service on a flight is not hazardous to passengers' health, especially when they have no access to food and drinks elsewhere?
If airlines delay meal service to allow passengers to disembark, why not also provide access to airport food and drinks to mitigate potential health risks from excessive delays?
If passengers' health and well-being are at risk due to delayed meal service, why should airlines not prioritize timely food delivery or provide alternative options for those in need?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: If airlines are allowed to sell tickets at prices that are not guaranteed to secure a seat, do they not then act as sellers of false promises, rather than providers of travel services?

Do airline industry experts agree that passengers should not have a legitimate expectation of being transported to their destination as promised when purchasing a ticket at a specific price, given that airlines reserve the right to deny boarding and compensation?
If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, why is the treatment of passengers bumped due to overbooking seen as acceptable?
If airline tickets are not lottery tickets, then why do airlines treat passengers who have paid less for their tickets or used frequent flyer miles with less consideration when they are bumped?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: If airlines are not incentivized to schedule properly due to low compensation, do you think they will be able to effectively prioritize the needs and expectations of their passengers?
Can you provide a scientific study that supports the claim that airlines should be incentivized to prioritize passengers based on the fare paid rather than confirmed bookings?

If the airline's primary incentive is to maximize revenue, would this not encourage them to prioritize higher-paying passengers over lower-paying ones, effectively creating a form of discriminatory scheduling?

If airlines are allowed to discriminate against lower-fared passengers, wouldn't that create an unfair advantage for those willing to pay more, essentially allowing the airlines to manipulate the system and prioritize profits over customer satisfaction?

as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?

cqs.cq: Should airlines inform passengers about potential allergens like peanuts before they purchase a ticket, potentially affecting their decision to fly?

If Delta is aware of the potential risk of peanut allergies, shouldn't they take more proactive measures to inform and accommodate passengers before they purchase a flight?

relation

I feel that they really wanted me to come to that conclusion
I did a great job and a great service not only for the country , but even for the president , in getting him to produce his birth certificate"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's ability to get the president to produce the birth certificate actually reflect his ability to heal racial tensions and improve relationships with the African-American community?
Do you have any credible evidence or scientific studies that support the claim that you have developed "very, very good relationships" with the African-American community?
If healing a racial divide requires great job and service, why should healing a racial divide be seen as less significant than healing a personal matter such as obtaining a birth certificate?
If Trump claims he did a great job in getting Obama to produce his birth certificate, then why is he now asking for information about Biden's birth certificate?

TRUMP_174_2.input:
TRUMP: "I also notice the very nasty commercials that you do on me in so many different ways , which I do n't do on you
Maybe I 'm trying to save the money
is n't that amazing
I settled that lawsuit with no admission of guilt , but that was a lawsuit brought against many real estate firms , and it 's just one of those things
I 'll go one step further
In Palm Beach , Florida , tough community , a brilliant community , a wealthy community , probably the wealthiest community there is in the world , I opened a club , and really got great credit for it
No discrimination against African- Americans, against Muslims, against anybody
it's a tremendously successful club
I'm so glad I did it
 I have been given great credit for what I did
'm very, very proud of it
that's the way I feel
That is the true way I feel"

cqs.cq: Does Trump's claim of having a nondiscriminatory club in Palm Beach, Florida, effectively outweigh his history of lawsuits and allegations of discriminatory practices?
Can you provide a credible source to support the claim that your club in Palm Beach, Florida, has no history of racial or ethnic discrimination?

If Trump's actions in Palm Beach, Florida, are seen as a model for non-discrimination, why do his policies and actions as a national leader not reflect a similar commitment to equality and justice for all?
Does opening a club in a wealthy community like Palm Beach, Florida, really demonstrate a genuine commitment to equality and non-discrimination, or is it just a public relations ploy?

TRUMP_183.input:
TRUMP: "I do want to say that I was just endorsed
and more are coming next week
it will be over 200 admirals
many of them here—admirals and generals endorsed me to lead this country
That just happened
many more are coming
I was just endorsed by ICE
They 've never endorsed anybody before on immigration
I was just recently endorsed—16,500 Border Patrol agents
when Secretary Clinton talks about this , I mean , I 'll take the admirals and I 'll take the generals any day over the political hacks that I see that have led our country so brilliantly over the last 10 years with their knowledge
look at the mess that we 're in
As far as the cyber , I agree to parts of what Secretary Clinton said
We should be better than anybody else
perhaps we 're not
I do n't think anybody knows it was Russia that broke into the DNC"

cqs.cq: If a president who has been endorsed by military and law enforcement officials is more effective in addressing national security concerns, then why does that endorsement not translate to better cybersecurity measures?
Do you have any credible sources to support the claim that the endorsement of military officials and law enforcement agencies is a reliable indicator of a candidate's leadership abilities?

If endorsing a politician based solely on the opinions of military leaders and law enforcement officials is a valid measure of their leadership capabilities, why would that not also be a valid measure of a politician's stance on immigration?
If the military and law enforcement officials endorse you over your opponent, does that necessarily imply that they have more faith in your leadership than in your opponent's?

TRUMP_192.input:
TRUMP: "President Obama and Secretary Clinton created a vacuum the way they got out of Iraq
they got out—what , they should n't have been in
once they got in , the way they got out was a disaster
ISIS was formed
she talks about taking them out
She 's been doing it a long time
She 's been trying to take them out for a long time
they would n't have even been formed if they left some troops behind , like 10,000 or maybe something more than that
then you would n't have had them
as I 've been saying for a long time
I think you 'll agree
I said it to you once
had we taken the oil—and we should have taken the oil—ISIS would not have been able to form either
we should have taken the oil
the oil was their primary source of income
now they have the oil all over the place
including the oil—a lot of the oil in Libya
was another one of her disasters"

cqs.cq: Would leaving troops behind in Iraq have prevented the formation of ISIS, or would other factors have still led to its emergence?
Can you provide a credible source to support your claim that leaving 10,000 troops behind in Iraq would have prevented the formation of ISIS?
If the US military had left a residual force behind in Iraq, would that be comparable to leaving a legacy of colonial occupation?
If the presence of US troops would have prevented ISIS from forming, does that imply that their formation was solely a result of the US withdrawal and not a complex mix of factors?

TRUMP_202_1.input:
TRUMP: "The secretary said very strongly about working with—we've been working with them for many years, and we have the greatest mess anyone's ever seen
You look at the Middle East, it's a total mess
Under your direction, to a large extent
you look at the Middle East, you started the Iran deal, that's another beauty where you have a country that was ready to fall, I mean, they were doing so badly
They were choking on the sanctions
now they're going to be actually probably a major power at some point pretty soon, the way they're going
when you look at NATO
I was asked on a major show, what do you think of NATO
you have to understand, I'm a businessperson
I did really well
I have common sense. And I said, well, I'll tell you. I haven't given lots of thought to NATO. But two things
the 28 countries of NATO, many of them aren't paying their fair share"

cqs.cq: If Trump's lack of foreign policy experience led to the creation of the Iran deal, does that make him more or less likely to create effective solutions to the Middle East's problems?
Can you provide a credible source that supports the claim that being a businessperson equips one with the necessary qualifications to make informed foreign policy decisions?

If the United States government's ability to manage international relations is compared to a business, why would the performance of a business be solely measured by its profits rather than its long-term impact on global stability?
If you've been working with the Middle East for many years and claim to have seen a great mess, how can you justify your administration's role in exacerbating that mess?

TRUMP_202_2.input:
TRUMP: "that bothers me
we should be asking—we're defending them, and they should at least be paying us what they're supposed to be paying by treaty and contract
NATO could be obsolete
I was very strong on this, and it was actually covered very accurately in the New York Times, which is unusual for the New York Times, to be honest—but I said, they do not focus on terror
 I was very strong. And I said it numerous times
about four months ago, I read on the front page of the Wall Street Journal that NATO is opening up a major terror division
that's great. And I think we should get
we pay approximately 73 percent of the cost of NATO
It's a lot of money to protect other people. But I'm all for NATO. But I said they have to focus on terror, also
they're going to do that
 I'm not going to get credit for it—but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO
we have to get NATO to go into the Middle East with us, in addition to surrounding nations, and we have to knock the hell out of ISIS, and we have to do it fast
when ISIS formed in this vacuum created by Barack Obama and Secretary Clinton. And believe me, you were the ones that took out the troops. Not only that, you named the day. They couldn't believe it. They sat back probably and said, I can't believe it"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that the US pays 73% of the cost of NATO lead to a lack of accountability and effectiveness in the alliance's efforts to address terror threats?

Do you have a credible source to support the claim that you were the primary reason for NATO's shift in focus to combat terrorism, as opposed to other factors such as changes in global security threats or shifting alliances?

If the US is expecting NATO allies to pull their weight in counter-terrorism efforts, would it not be equally reasonable to expect the US to contribute its fair share of financial and military support to its own allies?

If the US pays 73% of NATO's costs, and we're expecting them to focus on terror, then why shouldn't we expect other countries to contribute more to the alliance if they're expecting us to bear the bulk of the costs?

TRUMP_222.input:
TRUMP: "I have much better judgment than she does
There 's no question about that
I also have a much better temperament than she has
she spent hundreds of millions of dollars on an advertising
they get Madison Avenue into a room
they put names
temperament , let 's go after
my strongest asset , maybe by far , is my temperament
I have a winning temperament
I know how to win
She does not have a
Wrong
there 's a person with a temperament that 's got a problem
The AFL-CIO the other day , behind the blue screen , I do n't know who you were talking to , Secretary Clinton , but you were totally out of control
 I do n't know who you were talking to"

cqs.cq: If Trump's temperament is indeed as volatile as he suggests, can it effectively lead to a more divisive and unstable presidency?
Can you provide evidence from a scientific study that supports your claim that you have a 'winning temperament'?
If a businessman's wealth and ability to fund advertisements are seen as assets, would that not be comparable to a politician's ability to fund her own campaign?
Is it fair to claim superior judgment and temperament when your response to criticism involves dismissing and belittling your opponent?

TRUMP_236.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not an accurate one at all
It 's not an accurate one
I just want to give a lot of things
just to respond
I agree with her on one thing
The single greatest problem the world has is nuclear armament , nuclear weapons
not global warming
like you think
your—your president thinks
Nuclear is the single greatest threat
Just to go down the list , we defend Japan , we defend Germany , we defend South Korea , we defend Saudi Arabia , we defend countries
They do not pay us
they should be paying us
we are providing tremendous service
we 're losing a fortune
we 're losing
we lose on everything
All I said , that it 's very possible that if they do n't pay a fair share
this is n't 40 years ago where we could do what we 're doing
if they do n't pay a fair share
We ca n't defend Japan , a behemoth , selling us cars by the million"

cqs.cq: If the United States is losing a fortune on defending countries that do not pay a fair share, then why not reevaluate the current defense strategy to prioritize countries that contribute more to their own defense?

Can you provide a scientific source that supports the claim that countries that do not pay the United States for its defense services are equivalent to a "behemoth" selling the US cars by the million?

If the United States provides defense services to countries like Japan and Saudi Arabia without receiving payment, would it not be accurate to describe the relationship between the US and other nations as more akin to a patronage system than a fair trade?
If we prioritize defending countries that do not contribute to our defense costs, is it fair to expect other nations to pay for our military protection?

TRUMP_240_1.input:
TRUMP: "for what Secretary Clinton was saying about nuclear with Russia , she 's very cavalier in the way she talks about various countries
Russia has been expanding their
they have a much newer capability than we do
We have not been updating from the new standpoint
I looked the other night
I was seeing B-52s
they 're old enough that your father , your grandfather could be flying them
we are not keeping up with other countries
 I would like everybody to end it
just get rid of it
I would certainly not do first strike
once the nuclear alternative happens , it 's over
At the same time , we have to be prepared
I ca n't take anything off the table
you look at some of these countries , you look at North Korea , we 're doing nothing there
China should solve that problem for us
China should go into North Korea
China is totally powerful as it relates to North Korea"

cqs.cq: If the United States fails to modernize its nuclear capabilities, does this lack of investment lead to a significant increase in the likelihood of nuclear threats from other countries?
Can you provide a scientific source that supports your claim that Russia has a more advanced nuclear capability than the US?
If the US struggles to keep up with Russia's nuclear capabilities, why would we expect China to be able to solve North Korea's nuclear issues without significant US involvement?
If the United States cannot keep up with Russia's nuclear capabilities, why should we expect China to solve the problem of North Korea's nuclear threats?

CL_8.input:
CL: "Doesn’t it worry you at all that you're taking advantage of people when they are really in no position to negotiate?
They have absolutely very little choice except to take the terms that are being offered to them"

cqs.cq: Does this exploitation of vulnerable individuals have a detrimental effect on their well-being and trust in the system?

Do you have any evidence from a reputable academic source that supports the claim that individuals in vulnerable positions are more likely to engage in exploitative relationships with those who take advantage of them?

If exploiting individuals in vulnerable positions to gain economic benefits is considered unjust, wouldn't that also apply to the way corporations often interact with consumers who are desperate for basic necessities?
If you claim to be acting in their best interests, then why do your actions seem to prioritize your own interests over theirs?

MT_14.input:
MT: "We have indeed required those products to have very large warnings on them, telling people about their salt and fat content
And we don’t allow them to say things which are misleading
We don’t allow fatty products to say they're healthy
I've got in front of me a letter from a credit card company
There are two figures on this letter which really stand out: 0% per annum new balance transfers, 0% per annum new money transfers
Now, underneath that, in small print, it becomes absolutely clear that you’ll be paying all sorts of charges
And then very, very quickly you’ll be lured into paying a very large charge
Do you think it’s responsible to encourage people to mis-read something like that?
I’ve got all the information there in front of me
Why is that irresponsible?"

cqs.cq: Does the lack of transparency in credit card terms cause consumers to make uninformed financial decisions?
Do you believe that a credit card company's fine print disclosure is sufficient to excuse consumers from being misled by an advertisement that presents a false impression of a 0% interest rate?

If we hold food manufacturers responsible for the misinterpretation of their labeling, why should credit card companies be exempt from similar scrutiny for their potentially misleading promotional tactics?
If you claim to be transparent with consumers about the fine print of credit card offers, why do you hide the significant fees in small print instead of clearly disclosing them upfront?

MT_45.input:
MT: "Claire’s absolutely right about that
But then the problem is that that form of capitalism wasn’t generating sufficient surpluses
And so therefore where did the money flow
It didn’t flow into those industrial activities
 because in the developed world that wasn’t making enough money"

cqs.cq: If industrial activities were generating sufficient surpluses, would the money have flowed into those sectors and potentially alleviated the economic issues?
Can you provide a credible economic source that supports the claim that developed-world industries were not generating sufficient surpluses to justify the flow of capital?
If a capitalist system is only profitable when it exploits the masses, would that not be comparable to a system of slavery?
If capitalism isn't generating sufficient surpluses, then why should we rely on it as a primary economic model?

ND_23.input:
ND: " I think in the current situation that both savers and borrowers, if you're talking about individual people, are doing extremely badly
many people are unable to make ends meet and are having to take debt out at huge levels of interest
On the other hand, savers are earning nothing in interest
And what this needs is not simply us putting moral blame on one side or the other
but actually putting moral blame on a set of economic policies and political decisions that have led to credit liberalisation."

cqs.cq: Do the economic policies leading to credit liberalisation cause the financial struggles experienced by both borrowers and savers?
Do you have a peer-reviewed study that supports the claim that credit liberalisation is the primary cause of individuals struggling to make ends meet and earning low interest on savings?

If savers are unfairly penalized by earning nothing in interest, why should borrowers be viewed as solely responsible for their financial struggles rather than the economic policies that enable such exploitative lending practices?
If savers and borrowers are both struggling under the current economic system, does that imply that credit liberalisation is a double-edged sword that disproportionately affects both sides?

CF_62.input:
CF: "RS: Provide that for our young people
 These are young adults; you’re kind of treating them as though they’re passive recipients of something.
 And I suppose that’s my concern; how do we encourage the young?
It’s not beyond the imagination to imagine the young might get up and go and do something about this, other than kind of sit and wait to be handed something.
Now you’re saying “Provide that for our young people”, and in a way that’s where I’m going."

cqs.cq: If we provide everything for our young people, do we inadvertently prevent them from developing the initiative and agency necessary to create meaningful change?

Do you have any scientific evidence that supports the claim that young adults are typically passive recipients of information rather than active participants in their own learning and personal development?
If we're encouraging young people to be proactive and take charge of their own futures, why do we still treat them as passive recipients of handouts and entitlements?
If we are truly empowering our young people, shouldn't we also give them agency to take action, rather than simply providing them with something to wait for?

JW_35.input:
JW: "JW has got a rather nuanced view, that the way they're mis-used can have morally damaging consequences
Well, debt is morally neutral in the sense that it can be good to be in debt
 Sometimes it’s a good idea, and sometimes it’s a bad idea
And so I think there’s been broad agreement about that in the discussion so far
The question is why is there too much debt?
 Why are people taking on too much debt?
 this one is the elaboration of the previous question Now,
a lot of people come up with rather glib moral answers: somehow bankers want them to get into excessive debt
 which is a very peculiar idea, when you think that it’s the bankers who aren’t going to get repaid. So it’s a very odd idea
there’s too much debt for the same reason that there are too many unmarried mothers, and for the same reason that you get an overproduction of sheep."

cqs.cq: If the primary motivation for taking on excessive debt is not driven by bankers or external factors, but rather by individual choices, then why should we not hold individuals morally accountable for their financial decisions?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support your claim that bankers are not the primary cause of excessive debt among consumers?
If a financial system is likened to a market that can be prone to overproduction, would that not imply that the primary issue lies with the system itself rather than the individuals within it?
If debt is morally neutral and can be beneficial in some situations, then why should we apply moral judgment to the issue of excessive debt?

CLINTON_1_1.input:
CLINTON: "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we 'll build together
Today is my granddaughter 's second birthday
I think about this a lot
we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes
I want us to invest in you
I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business
We also have to make the economy fairer
That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee , finally , equal pay for women 's work
I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

cqs.cq: If we create an economy that works for everyone, as you propose, will that lead to a decrease in the wealth gap and an increase in social mobility?
What specific economic indicators and data would you use to measure the success of your proposed economic policies in achieving a more equitable society?

If building an economy that works for everyone is a key goal, why would prioritizing profit-sharing among corporate leaders not be seen as a more equitable solution than solely raising the national minimum wage?
If we're investing in the future of everyone, why is the national minimum wage not already a living wage?

TRUMP_99.input:
TRUMP: "I will release them as soon as the audit
I 've been under audit almost for 15 years
I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited
I said , do you get audited
do you get audited
I get audited almost every year
in a way , I should be complaining
I 'm not even complaining
I do n't mind it
It 's almost become a way of life
I get audited by the IRS
But other people don't
We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of
I will release my tax returns—against my lawyer 's wishes—when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted
As soon as she releases them , I will release
I will release my tax returns
that 's against—my lawyers
they say , `` Do n't do it . '' I will tell you this
No—in fact , watching shows , they 're reading the papers
Almost every lawyer says , you do n't release your returns until the audit 's complete
When the audit 's complete , I 'll do it
I would go against them if she releases her e-mails"

cqs.cq: If releasing tax returns during an ongoing audit could lead to the discovery of discrepancies, then why would it be beneficial for an individual to release their tax returns during such a process?
Do you have any evidence or credible sources that suggest the audit process is so uniquely grueling that it warrants holding onto tax returns for 15 years?
If Trump's tax returns are not released until the audit is complete, why would Biden's emails be released before the audit of his son Hunter is complete?
If you claim to be transparent and willing to release your tax returns, why do you insist on waiting for your lawyer's approval and only release them after she releases her deleted emails?

TRUMP_174_1.input:
TRUMP: "I would love to respond
I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama
You treated him with terrible disrespect
I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are
It does n't work that way
You were after him
you were trying to—you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb , very famous pictures
I do n't think you can deny that
just last week , your campaign manager said it was true
when you tried to act holier than thou , it really does n't work
as far as the lawsuit , yes , when I was very young , I went into my father 's company , had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens , and we , along with many , many other companies throughout the country—it was a federal lawsuit—were sued
We settled the suit with zero—with no admission of guilt
It was very easy to do
I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.cq: If he was as innocent as he claims, why does he continue to deflect and deny any wrongdoing when questioned about it?
Can you provide a scientific source to support the claim that women are more likely to be "after" a presidential candidate than men?

If you're implying that you're holier than Obama by questioning his character, then can you explain why you're deflecting from your own controversies by bringing up his lawsuit?

TRUMP_112.input:
TRUMP: "That was more than a mistake
That was done purposely
That was not a mistake
When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment , taking the Fifth so they 're not prosecuted
when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also
As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: If having a staff member take the Fifth Amendment and the person responsible for setting up an illegal server also take the Fifth, then is it not reasonable to infer that there was intentional wrongdoing rather than a mistake?
Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that the country thinks it's 'disgraceful' for someone to have their staff take the Fifth Amendment?

If one takes the Fifth Amendment to avoid prosecution for illegal actions, does that not undermine the integrity of an institution, just as Trump's actions are seen to undermine the trust in the presidency?
If taking the Fifth Amendment is considered "disgraceful" in this context, does that imply that President Trump holds himself to a different standard than his staff and others?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: Would a president who often relies on impulse and rhetoric over fact and diplomacy be more likely to cause a war with Iran?
Does any credible expert support the claim that America's word is inherently more trustworthy under your leadership compared to that of your opponent?

If a country's word is considered a vital component of its international relationships, does the United States' reputation as a reliable partner still hold value after breaking its promise to withdraw troops from Afghanistan?
If America's word is good, then why did the US not honor its promise to withdraw from the 1954 SEATO treaty after the North Vietnamese attacked Cambodia, leading to a devastating war?
